FYI Swing Left is a scam
WRITING.TEXT: There's [a link](https://www.reddit.com/r/esist/comments/69eda3/700000_raised_to_unseat_republicans_who_voted_for/) on the front page right now bragging about Swing Left raising several hundred thousand to fight AHCA supporters. Don't donate to their "District Nominee Funds". It's a variation of a well-known scam, mostly seen on the right, but increasingly among Democratic-aligned groups, to come up with PACs and committees with generic names like "End Citizens United" or ["National Pro-Life Committee"](http://www.liveaction.org/news/new-phone-scam-targets-pro-lifers-with-fake-donation-request/). These groups are supposedly created to do electoral work and/or advocacy, but the scam is designed to funnel massive amounts of money back to the scammers. Here's a [great Politico writeup](http://www.politico.com/story/2016/08/donald-trump-fundraiser-hawes-227486 ) of how a scam PAC duped Trump supporters out of millions of dollars. Here's how the scam works: 1. File FEC paperwork to create a PAC or other type of committee 2. Buy or rent an email list of online donors, and send start sending these people emails about how they need to fight back against X issue RIGHT NOW by donating $10, which will be triple-matched, and #resist. Raise hundreds of thousands, or sometimes millions of dollars this way. 3. Now, you're sitting on a bunch of money that you were supposed to use for electoral purposes, and you need to launder it to yourself. First, pay yourself and your friends a six-figure salary out of PAC funds for the hard, hard work of running the PAC (i.e. drafting the email blast) 3a. Then, set up a fundraising consulting company that you own, and pay yourself a few million dollars for "fundraising consulting". 3b. Usually, at this point, you've laundered all the money. But sometimes, you duped donors [so successfully that there's money left over, and you're being scrutinized.](http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/end-citizens-united-pac-campaign-finance-reform_us_570e5308e4b0ffa5937da409). So, set up a media buying firm. Take 10 minutes on Windows Movie Maker to make a bunch of trashy, ineffective ads with stock footage. Then, start running ads on cable, or hell, even Youtube. Make sure to take a 15% agency commission and a few hundred grand for media production costs. Oh, and since you're a Super PAC, you're paying twice what the candidates are paying for the same TV time. **Swing Left** Like I said, Swing Left is a variant of this scam. They've set up a bunch of ["District Nominee funds"](https://swingleft.org/district-funds) and they take [10% of your donation amount](https://secure.actblue.com/contribute/page/swing-AL-02-left), unless you email them specifically and ask that the 10% go directly to the candidate too. This "email us to change the allocation" thing is odd, since ActBlue allows committees to set up pages that split donations between multiple entities (such as between a candidate and a PAC). But they know most people won't bother emailing, which is why they've set it up that way. Swing Left is hoping that they raise several million dollars over the next couple of years, and they can pay themselves six or even seven figure salaries out of their 10% cut. What's their add-value for that 10%, which will inevitably total millions of dollars? That they create ActBlue fundraising pages. That's literally just it. They spent 1 minute each setting up an ActBlue page for each swing congressional district, and they have a pretty website. That's not worth siphoning millions of dollars from House candidates next cycle. Between propping up grifters like Louise Mensch, and sending money to scam groups like Swing Left... Democrats are dangerously close to fucking this up.

It turns out the Senate Republican bill already includes a reinsurance fund for insurers which is....$15 billion for each of the next 2 years- which is *exactly* the same as the CAP proposal. Horseshoe theory confirmed. Pack it up, everyone, we're done here. Mitch McConnell and CAP came to the same healthcare proposal independently. https://twitter.com/sahilkapur/status/880441260670103553

That's untrue, and in fact, she defended death penalty cases in the South as part of the Center for Death Penalty Litigation, and then founded the Fair Trial Initiative which has become a fairly prominent nonprofit in that area of law two decades later.

I mean, you could just come out and admit you were wrong instead of keeping on bullshitting. You were just corrected on the fact that she was a practicing attorney, on capital cases no less, and for a state that has the 6th largest death row in the country. Now tell me the last time Schneiderman actually argued a case in front of a judge or wrote a motion on his own. Please. Indulge us.
Do *you* understand what the AG does? Are you under impression that Schneiderman was sitting around all day typing up motions? Or that he's prosecuting common criminals?

I mean she was a death penalty lawyer and now teaches the law, so, uh, I'd say she has enough of a "hardcore understanding of the law", and certainly about as much or more than Eric Scheniderman or Andrew Cuomo did when they joined the office. Seriously, what a short memory that guy above you has. Cuomo was his father's political operative turned HUD secretary, Schneiderman was never a litigator. The last AG with prosecutorial experience was Spitzer, more than a decade ago....

In what world is the AG arguing cases in a courtroom? The AG's power comes from being able to set priorities based on values and political mandates. Second of all, Schneiderman was never a litigator; he was a corporate paperwork lawyer and then burnished his public service resume with more paperwork advocacy stuff.

Eric Schneiderman had never been a prosecutor, nor had he ever been in law enforcement. Same for Andrew Cuomo. Meanwhile, Teachout litigated death penalty cases and actually co-founded one of the more prominent capital case nonprofits in the country

How the fuck is this anti\-Asian in the slightest? The spots are reserved for low\-income kids. The most likely scenario is that more Asian kids on net are going to be in the high schools, and the mix is going to tilt towards more working class kids than the kids of lawyers and doctors

Halal chicken over rice
Exactly. Setting aside spots for low\-income students doesn't hurt Asians, it helps them \(on net\)

I don't support the plan to scrap the test, but the idea that the current test is predictive is not correct. The SAT results you're seeing could just as easily (if not more easily) be explained by a better quality education at those schools. In fact, folks at the DOE itself has said the test is not particularly predictive of academic results down the line.
If the issue is helping poor kids, let's reserve 50%\+ of the spots for low income kids at the schools. But that's not what BdB is proposing.

They probably could expand the schools. The thing is that the schools themselves aren't that great. Class sizes are average, some teachers are good while others are bad...there's little special about the schools themselves.

She straight up called ICE a terrorist organization. Even AOC didn't do that. Cynthia Nixon, despite being a millionaire, has landed with surprisingly fantastic politics. There really isn't a single issue in her questionnaire where you see liberal hand-wringing. I'd prefer if Bernie Sanders and AOC and Nixon came out and all said- yes, we want worker ownership over the means of production, not just a bigger welfare state - but even popularizing the label is huge from where we were just a few years ago

They are paid too much, even though that's not exactly what she said, and even though she's walked that back. So are NYC cops. Cuomo has made a nice corrupt deal with the TWU and LIUNA that spikes transit costs for the working class while developers and a handful of union members rake it in. The base pay rate for LIUNA 147 is $111 per hour, which quadruples to more than **$400 per hour** during weekend overtime, which, in practice, is when a lot of the work happens. That money mostly comes from fare increases on poor people. NYC's transit system is \*\*absolutely\*\* an example of the means of production extracting massive rents from the vast majority of working families to benefit a select group of crony capitalists and politically connected people who happen to be in labor. **Bottom line: When one class of laborer can't even scrape together $15 an hour, and another class of mostly white, male, politically connected worker is making $400+ an hour off the backs of regressive taxes on those lt;$15/hr workers, that itself is a source of social inequality** [https://www.nytimes.com/2017/12/28/nyregion/new-york-subway-construction-costs.html](https://www.nytimes.com/2017/12/28/nyregion/new-york-subway-construction-costs.html)
And Nixon's actual plan to fund the MTA is, in fact, a millionaire's tax and congestion pricing.

Sorry, you are misunderstanding the way it works. The party nominates people for their line. WFP assumed Crowley would win the primary, and they gave him the line. It's incredibly common in cases where people don't win the Dem primary to leave the WFP line. Crowley himself arranged a lot of this as head of the Queens party machine. Him refusing to leave the line is just straight fuckery.

No, you missed the 4th way, which is the way people actually do it, which is to get swapped for a minor judgeship somewhere else in the state on the WFP line that you wouldn't win. He's refusing to do that
He wasn't a write-in. WFP gave him their line; he was the only person on the WFP line. He can absolutely decline the nom by participating in a ballot swap. It's incredibly common in NY. He's refusing

It doesn't make declining the nomination hard. He just agrees to let WFP swap him for a dummy judgeship seat on their line elsewhere in the state. It's very common, and something Crowley himself has orchestrated for political allies in the past. He's refusing.

WRITING.TITLE: Love to be a union leader and lick Cuomo's boots...

WRITING.TEXT: She's a grifter

Wow- honestly a staggeringly glowing endorsement. Usually the NYT hems and haws about the various candidates for a little bit and then does a few positive sentences about the endorsee. This is the office that perfectly fits her skillset as an anti-corruption leader so she's got my vote

Also, she: 1. Was the first-ever national director of the Sunlight Foundation, the top anti-corruption civil society organization at the time (she made it hat) 2. Has done seminal work in the history of corruption and the law in the United States, to the point where her work was cited in the dissent to the Citizens United case in the Supreme Court 3. Has been a co-plaintiff and key lawyer in CREW's anti-corruption lawsuits against Trump - a legal strategy that has been recently vindicated by the courts, by the way Moreover, just look at the way she's funding her campaign. All small individual donors, no anonymous LLCs and no real estate money. In a state where LLCs can write six figure checks to political candidates, it takes quite a bit of willpower to abstain from that to maintain your prosecutorial independence. She's done so, and she's the only candidate in the race doing so. She's serious about fighting corruption, even if that puts her at a political disadvantage. That kind of integrity is golden, especially in the swamp of Albany.
